message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain, and sudden death in a family member, together with the physical examination findings of a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur, suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The Valsalva maneuver causing a louder murmur is a known feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Aortic stenosis may also present with a systolic murmur, but the absence of a late-peaking crescendo murmur and the presence of an early diastolic murmur make this option less likely. First-degree heart block and third-degree heart block do not fit this clinical picture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is characterized by a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur heard best with the bell of the stethoscope. The murmur becomes louder with the Valsalva maneuver. Aortic stenosis may present with symptoms similar to the patient but the murmur is heard best at the base of the heart, radiates to the neck, and is not affected by the Valsalva maneuver. First-degree and third-degree heart block do not present with murmurs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings point to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). HCM is a genetic disease that causes thickening of the heart muscle, leading to restricted blood flow and increased risk of sudden death, which is in line with the patient's brother's sudden death. The murmur heard is consistent with HCM, and the Valsalva maneuver making the murmur louder is a characteristic finding. Aortic stenosis typically presents with a systolic murmur heard best over the right upper sternal border and does not radiate to the axilla. First-degree and third-degree heart block do not typically present with murmurs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings, along with the family history, strongly suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Aortic stenosis can present with a harsh systolic murmur, but HCM is more likely given the early diastolic murmur, which is not characteristic of aortic stenosis. First-degree and third-degree heart block are unlikely given the patient’s symptoms and physical findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the syncope, shortness of breath, and chest pain upon exertion suggest cardiovascular disease. The harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur and early diastolic murmur heard on physical examination, as well as the findings on the Valsalva maneuver and echocardiogram, suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy as the most likely cause. Aortic stenosis typically presents in older patients and would not cause an early diastolic murmur. First- and third-degree heart block are unlikely causes of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a systolic heart murmur that is best heard on the apex and radiates to the axilla, which suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The early diastolic murmur is consistent with mitral insufficiency caused by systolic anterior motion of the anterior mitral valve leaflet. The Valsalva maneuver increases the mitral regurgitant murmur. The symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain upon exertion, and syncope are also common in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including shortness of breath, chest pain upon exertion, and syncope, suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). The harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur and the early diastolic murmur heard with the bell of the stethoscope are typical for HCM. The Valsalva maneuver makes the murmur louder, which is also consistent with HCM. Aortic stenosis can cause a systolic murmur, but it would not be heard in the apex and would not be associated with an early diastolic murmur. First-degree and third-degree heart block would not cause the symptoms or murmurs described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation, including exertional syncope, chest pain, and a family history of sudden cardiac death, suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The presence of both a systolic and a diastolic murmur also supports this diagnosis. Aortic stenosis would present with a systolic murmur but not a diastolic murmur. First-degree and third-degree heart block would not present with these types of murmurs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a harsh systolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur heard best on the apex, which radiates to the axilla. This is consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can cause sudden death in young athletes. The Valsalva maneuver can increase the intensity of the murmur in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Aortic stenosis also causes a systolic murmur, but it is heard best at the right upper sternal border and does not radiate to the axilla. First-degree heart block and third-degree heart block do not cause the characteristic murmurs of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the syncope, shortness of breath, and chest pain upon exertion, suggest hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The presence of a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur heard in early diastole, which is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope, support this diagnosis as well. The fact that the murmur becomes louder with the Valsalva maneuver is also consistent with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Aortic stenosis typically has a systolic murmur that radiates to the carotids, while first-degree and third-degree heart block do not typically present with these symptoms.
